fields.title: A Different Time
fields.description: Image of a dark skinned woman viewed from the back looking out over the beach and onto the distant horizon of sea and white clouds in the sky.. She has a white hat with blue ribbons flowing from the hat.   There is a slip of the sea that can been seen with white clouds in the background creating a sense of distance to the sea.  .

fields.title: A Pause to Look
fields.description: A small exquiste painting with an outstanding composition effectively using space on a dune beach near the ocean.  A young man in the foreground is seen standing from the left profile view. He is dressed in white beach pants and a white beach shirt blowing slightly in the wind.  He has bare feet and there is a slight feeling of movement as he looks over his right shoulder toward a woman figure in the left background who has her back toward him as she appears to be viewing the ocean.  She is wearing a horiontal white and red beach sorrang.

fields.title: Air of the Sea

Her right arm is extended down along the folds of her skirt.  There currently are two balloons flowing slightly to her right as she walks along the beach towards the ocean. fields.title: Bather in Red
fields.description: Oil on canvas. Image of a female bather in a red two piece suit. Elements of her body are divided by black lines into geometric shapes. Head is two colors - red and reddish-brown with a vertical curved line dividing the face at the nose. A horizontal line indicates the eyes and brow. Shades of green and blue separate the background.

fields.title: Beach Dance
fields.signature: Lower right under image of painting
fields.description:
Holding certificate at the studio
A dark black woman in a large white dress with a ruffled petticoat and a large, broad-brimmed hat with a white ribbon hatband walks away from the viewer on the beach. Two empty white shoes are in the viewer's right foreground. One shoe's opening faces the viewer and the other shoe leans upwards with its laces visibly untied. The woman is wearing a bow round her waist that is solid light blue one side with large blue polka-dots on the other side, in a field of white. Her dress has three buttons on the back and a fancy collar. The heels of both bare feet of the woman are visible as her right foot is placed in front of her, she picks up her left foot behind. Her left elbow is visible above her billowing dress. In front of her a blue sea swells. At her feet two-colors of sand show the shadow of her dress in the bright and direct sun. The light appears to be coming from directly overhead.
fields.notes:
last: Breakwell
first: Wendy

city: Barton

fields.notes: notes: This original silk screen print was produced at the Department of Art at the University of South Carolina in Columbia, SC The artist, Jonathan Green worked in collaboration with Gene Speer, Master Printer, for the printing and trial proofing and with Mary Robinson, Professor of Printmaking, for quality observation, assistance in printing and consultation with the artists. Assistant printers included Micah Cash, Jonathan Goley, Sara Kennedy and Denton Smith. Jonathan Green painted an initial study of Dance Hall Romance in gouache on paper, which guided th emaking of hand cut and painted stencils used in the printing. Eleven layers of silkscreen inks were used in the printing of this silkscreen. The preliminary study for this print was returned to Jonathan Green Studios, Inc. for its archival files. There are no prior or  ater editions in this series of original prints. Printed on Stonehenge Wrm White 250g, 9o Weight. Paper size 37" x 30"

fields.notes: notes: This original silk screen print was produced at the Department of Art at the University of South Carolina in Columbia, SC The artist, Jonathan Green worked in collaboration with Gene Speer, Master Printer, for the printing and trial proofing and with Mary Robinson, Professor of Printmaking, for quality observation, assistance in printing and consultation with the artists. Assistant printers included Micah Cash, Jonathan Goley, Sara Kennedy and Denton Smith. Jonathan Green painted an initial study of Dance Hall Romance in gouache on paper, which guided th emaking of hand cut and painted stencils used in the printing. Eleven layers of silkscreen inks were used in the printing of this silkscreen. The preliminary study for this print was returned to Jonathan Green Studios, Inc. for its archival files. There are no prior or  ater editions in this series of original prints. Printed on Stonehenge Wrm White 250g, 9o Weight. Paper size 37" x 30"

fields.title: Beach Dance 2/75
fields.description: A dark black woman in a large white dress with a ruffled petticoat and a large, broad-brimmed hat with a white ribbon hatband walks away from the viewer on the beach. Two empty white shoes are in the viewer's right foreground. One shoe's opening faces the viewer and the other shoe leans upwards with its laces visibly untied. The woman is wearing a bow round her waist that is solid light blue one side with large blue polka-dots on the other side, in a field of white. Her dress has three buttons on the back and a fancy collar. The heels of both bare feet of the woman are visible as her right foot is placed in front of her, she picks up her left foot behind. Her left elbow is visible above her billowing dress. In front of her a blue sea swells. At her feet two-colors of sand show the shadow of her dress in the bright and direct sun. The light appears to be coming from directly overhead.

Her left elbow is visible above her billowing dress. In front of her a blue sea swells. At her feet two-colors of sand show the shadow of her dress in the bright and direct sun. The light appears to be coming from directly overhead.

fields.title: Bessie's Best Sheets
fields.description: A young dark-skinned girl in a pinafore type dress with short, cuffed sleeves is looking away from the viewer in the foreground. She is center-right in the painting. She has a white bow in her hair, which appears to be somewhat wavy with highlights of brown and undertoens of dark brown and black. Her hair is cropped relatively short in a style indicative of a childhood haircut of mid-Twentieth Century America. Her dress appears to be picked up slightly by the wind, filling the bottom eighth of the painting. She is facing a large white sheet on a clothesline that is blowing gently in the breeze. The sheet is blown up just enough to see the grass and shadows peeking through below it. Above the sheet, at the top a clear blue sky peeks through, slightly lighter blue on the left. Direct sharp lighting indicates mid morning or noon light.

fields.title: Blue Sky Laundry
fields.description: A dark black woman wearing a broad-brimmed straw hat and a white dress with rounded, fluffed short sleeves is pendulously carrying a sweetgrass basket in her right hand. As she walks away from the viewer and towards a line of sheets the wind is picking up her dress lillowing it to the left, obscuring her left hand and arm. White sheets hang peacefully on the line beneath a completely clear blue sky in a flat, grassy field. From the shadows directly beneath the woman's dress and the harsh light it appears to be noon.

fields.description: Painting of a woman walking toward white sheets on the closeline.  She has a sweater haning over her back with the sleves of the sweater flowing left in the breeze.  She is seen from the back and is wearing a brown large straw hat with a red ribbon tied around the crown of the hat.  In her right arm she is carrying an empty sweetgrass wash basket. Her blue black arm is around the basket.  She is wearing a puple dress.  The two white sheets on the line are flowing left in the breeze.  There is green grass seen between the flowing sheets with what appears to be a horizon of trees in the background. The sky is blue with only a hint of potential clouds.

fields.title: Casting for Bait
fields.description: A dark-skinned (grey) young boy facing the viewer tosses a fishing net towards the viewer with his laft hand. The boy is wearing a yellow t-shirt and red shorts with a white horizontal stripe on each leg. The shorts go down to his knees. The boy appears to be standing in shallow blue water with flat green marshland and blue sky behind him. Th boy wears a brown straw hat with ruffed edges and a red hatband. His fishing net is tied to his left hand and is light grey. The fishing net partially obscures the top third of the painting, with the sky behind it a lighter hue than the sky below. The net is apparently over the head of the viewer and the boy tossing it.
fields.notes:
key: 14/75
comments: Place as a raffle item and Jonathan Green Jazz & Friends on Daniel Island May 22, 2011 and was won by Inna Metcalf.  She called for her certificate of autehnticity for this work on 3-31-2012.  Certificate sent to her March 31, 2012.
last: Metcalf
first: Inna
salutation: 1
address: 278 Furman Farm Place
city: Daniel Island
state: SC
zip: 29492-7304
telephone: 843 471-2405
notes: This original silk screen print was produced at the Department of Art at the University of South Carolina in Columbia, SC The artist, Jonathan Green worked in collaboration with Gene Speer, Master Printer, for the printing and trial proofing and with Mary Robinson, Professor of Printmaking, for quality observation, assistance in printing and consultation with the artists. Assistant printers included Micah Cash, Jonathan Goley, Sara Kennedy and Denton Smith. Jonathan Green painted an initial study of Dance Hall Romance in gouache on paper, which guided th emaking of hand cut and painted stencils used in the printing. Seventeen layers of silkscreen inks were used in the printing of this silkscreen. The preliminary study for this print was returned to Jonathan Green Studios, Inc. for its archival files. There are no prior or  ater editions in this series of original prints. Printed on Stonehenge Wrm White 250g, 9o Weight. Paper size 37" x 30"

fields.title: Casting for Bait 19/75
fields.description: A dark-skinned (grey) young boy facing the viewer tosses a fishing net towards the viewer with his laft hand. The boy is wearing a yellow t-shirt and red shorts with a white horizontal stripe on each leg. The shorts go down to his knees. The boy appears to be standing in shallow blue water with flat green marshland and blue sky behind him. Th boy wears a brown straw hat with ruffed edges and a red hatband. His fishing net is tied to his left hand and is light grey. The fishing net partially obscures the top third of the painting, with the sky behind it a lighter hue than the sky below. The net is apparently over the head of the viewer and the boy tossing it.

fields.notes: notes: This original silk screen print was produced at the Department of Art at the University of South Carolina in Columbia, SC The artist, Jonathan Green worked in collaboration with Gene Speer, Master Printer, for the printing and trial proofing and with Mary Robinson, Professor of Printmaking, for quality observation, assistance in printing and consultation with the artists. Assistant printers included Micah Cash, Jonathan Goley, Sara Kennedy and Denton Smith. Jonathan Green painted an initial study of Dance Hall Romance in gouache on paper, which guided th emaking of hand cut and painted stencils used in the printing. Seventeen layers of silkscreen inks were used in the printing of this silkscreen. The preliminary study for this print was returned to Jonathan Green Studios, Inc. for its archival files. There are no prior or  ater editions in this series of original prints. Printed on Stonehenge Wrm White 250g, 9o Weight. Paper size 37" x 30"

fields.title: Catfish Row
fields.signature: on Top of Painting on 1/3rd of ptng
fields.description:
Catfish Row aka Cabbage Row
Cabbage Row is a structure from the Revolutionary War era. It is a well preserved example of this type of home, consisting of a pair of houses connected by a central arcade. The structure is three stories tall with commercial ground floors that have stood the test of time. The area is now lined with private homes and specialty shops but that wasn’t always the case.
At one time, Cabbage Row was home to up to ten families at a time and was mostly inhabited by the African American families of freed slaves. This is also where the name, Cabbage Row, was born. African Americans living in these row houses would sell cabbage right from their window sills. The building continued to house a tenement into the early 1900s. Name was changed for Catfish Row based on Gershwin’s opera, Porgy and Bess.

fields.title: Corn Field
fields.description: A brownish mule wearing blinders is yoked to an old-fashioned ploughin the middle of a corn field where young corn plants are just beginning to grow. A bright yellow house with white trim and a front porch is in the distance. A large tree is growing near the house in the distance. In the foreground, in front of the mule is a black farmer in a straw hat wearing a white shirt and blue (jeans?) held up with suspenders, which form an X on his back. He is holding a metal bucket. Above the mule in the sky three dark birds (crows? pigeons?) are ascending. One of the birds is far, one is nearer and one is very close to the mule. The sky is blue with strands of white puffy clouds.
fields.notes:
copyright_x0020_submitted: 2004
last: Leftwich
first: Willie and Curtis
date_x0020_purchased: 08/23/04

fields.title: Corn Shed
fields.signature: On fencepost on the left side
fields.description: A brownish mule peeks at the viewer from behind the last rungs of a white farm fence in the center foreground of the painting. The mule is smallish and has his head down near the grass. The mule's tail is slightly raised. The field behind the fence is filled with tall, colorful grass. A white clapboard corn shed with a red roof is just behind the mule and easily seen  above the fence. It is located just right of center in the painting and has its door opened slightly inwards revealing the darkness inside. A leafy tree is just behind and to the right of the shed. In the far distance there is a small white house with green shutters and a red roof. The front porch on the house sways downward. Behind the house there is a small patch of leafy trees. In front of it, in the distance behind eth house, is another small patch of leafy trees. The sky above is blue tinged with red. A sliver of a moon is just above and left of the house. Stars are also in the sky. Some clouds are visible as it appears to be near dawn or sunset. The fence in the foreground is covered with a series of interesting shadows that appear to be from light filtering through trees.
fields.notes:
copyright_x0020_submitted: 2004
last: Leftwich
first: Willie and Curtis
date_x0020_purchased: 8/23/04

fields.description: Ink wash of bathers in Cozumel, Mexico. Line    drawings of tourists of various shapes and sizes. Rear view of a very large woman bather in a one piece suit. Reddish-brown tint to the wash used to define the contours of her flesh, especially the backs of her legs.

fields.title: Cozumel, jungle

shape: 14 by 10
comments: Done while in Cozumel, Mexico the Summer of 1982

fields.title: Cubistic Wild Planet
fields.description: Pencil and pastel drawing on paper. Futuristic and cubistic scene. Animals and humans have merged together creating imaginative creatures. Lack of depth of field or three dimensionality - compressed and layered. Pattern and color take over. Sexual undertones. Color include - purple, yellow, black, orange, blue, red, and green.
fields.condition: Good. Some smudges of the graphite pencil

fields.title: Dance Hall Roman*
fields.description: A man in the foreground faces away from the viewer as he dances with a woman who is facing the viewer. The man is wearing purple pants, a lime green shirt and a vest with wide, yellow and blue vertical stripes. He is also wearing a red hat with a lime green hatband and a blue feather on his left side. His skin appears pink, as he is probably an albino. The woman is wearing a tight-fitting red dress with white edges and a white bow. The dress is flared and pleated at the hemline. Her skin is chocolate brown and her hair is mauve. She has a yellow flower in her hair (her right side) and wears a lime green and a blue bracelet on her left arm. The background behind their faces and upper body is a pattern of black paisley-shapes on a white field. The lower background is grey and black.
fields.notes: notes: This original silk screen print was produced at the Department of Art at the University of South Caorlina in Columbia, SC The artist, Jonathan Green worked in collaboration with Gene Speer, Master Printer, for the printing and trial proofing and with Mary Robinson, Professor of Printmaking, for quality observation, assistance in printing and consultation with the artists. Assistant printers included Micah Cash, Jonathan Goley, Sara Kennedy and Denton Smith. Jonathan Green painted an initial study of Dance Hall Romance in gouache on paper, which guided th emaking of hand cut and painted stencils used in the printing. Twenty-three layers of silkscreen inks were used in the printing of this silkscreen. The preliminary study for this print was returned to Jonathan Green Studios, Inc. for its archival files. There are no prior or later editions in this series of original prints.

fields.title: Dance of Harvest
fields.description: A Young Woman Harvest worker runing ton toe sweet grass harvest field.  She has Blue jean under a red skirt with a white rom near the bottom of the skirt.  She is wearing a turqouise blue jacket and a green wide brimmed hat with a white cirlce trim with a black and white polka dot skcraf around the rim of the hat.  She is swinging a large puirble scark in the air.  There is a pink sky.

fields.title: Decoration Day
fields.description:
Now worth 60,000 as of April 25, 2005
DECORATION DAY

Decoration Day was observed by many small communities in the South following the end of the Civil War to remember and honor those who lost their lives during this war.  It also served as a time for many in small communities throughout South Carolina to fulfill a general human need to honor all those had passed.  Graves were often decorated and members of the community gathered for a sense of fellowship combined with picnics and related celebrations.

According to Professor David Blight of the Yale University History Department, “the first Decoration Day (Memorial Day) was observed by formerly enslaved black people at the Washington Race Course (today the location of Hampton Park in Charleston, South Carolina.)  The race course had been used as a temporary Confederate prison camp in 1865 as well as a mass grave for Union soldiers who died there.  Immediately after the cessation of hostilities, formerly enslaved people exhumed the bodies from the mass grave and reinterred them properly with individual graves.  They built a fence around the graveyard with an entry arch and declared it a Union graveyard.  The work was completed in only ten days.  On May, 1, 1865, The Charleston newspaper reported that a crowd of up to ten thousand, mainly black residents, including 2800 children, processed to the location for a celebration which included sermons, singing, and a picnic on the grounds, thereby creating the first Decoration Day.”

After the government incorporated Decoration Day into a Federal Memorial Day to honor all individuals who served and died during all American wars and changed the observation day and date to assure a three day week-end the specific meaning of Decoration Day began to fade.  Jonathan Green created the painting Decoration Day because this was still observed by his family and community members when he was a child.  Many children of today however do not understand the history of Decoration Day and the unique meaning it had to African-Americans in the South.

fields.title: Duke
fields.signature: At right bottom of painting on painted tree root
fields.description: A brownish mule enjoys some vividly colored swirls of grass between two leafy trees. The roots of the trees are painted white up to the lower trunks. One tree is in the right foreground and the other is in the left background. Beyond the tree a whitewashed farm fence runs from left to right. Beyond that the flat land seems to stretch for miles with small rolling hills in the distance. The sky is dark blue/black and tinged with red. Strands of clouds run left to right across the sky. The light indicates that the image is from near sunrise or sunset. Some stars are visible in the sky, behind the clouds.
fields.notes:
copyright_x0020_submitted: 2004
last: Leftwich
first: Willie and Curtis
date_x0020_purchased: 8/23/04

fields.title: Eyelets
fields.description:
The main subject is a young, dark black woman wearing a bright green broad-brimmed hat with a white ribbon and a brilliant red antique-style dress. The dress has a faint damask-like pattern in it and also has bright white eyelet on the hem, at the bust line and at the end of the dress’ buttoned-down balloon sleeves. The woman is swinging forcefully on a tree swing at an angle in the opposite direction of the viewer. The scene captures the moment at which the dress fills with air and fans out, creating a poppy-like shape around the woman’s body.

The swinging woman’s face is completely obscured by her hat. Shadows on the top of the hat echo the tree above her and show the intensity of the sun. White ribbon flows from beneath the hat, and lead to a white bow that his around her neck. The woman holds a substantial rope in each hand. She wears brilliant white socks with red ribbons in them that match her dress. The sky around her legs and socks is blue with a few white, puffy clouds. Tree branches and leaves frame the top of the image, hinting again at the tree upon which the swing hangs.

In the distance behind the swinging woman a patch of green grass and a small old style house with shutters and a front porch are visible.

fields.title: Festival Time
fields.description: Three woman in bright festival clothes walking away into a green field from the viewer.  All women have their backs to the viewer.  The woman in the foreground is wearing a bluse skirt with a red blouse and is wearig a dark blue scarf on her head along with a lare brimmed straw hat.   The other tow women who are wearing large staw brimed hats are dressked in festival outfits as well.  The second closest the to viewer is wearing a blue red and green horizontal large striped skirt with a yellow blouse and a black scarf on her hed with a yellow bandanna on the hat.  The third woman is wearingblack skirt aith an orange blouse and a green bandana.  There is a small white house on the far left hand corner of the painting.

fields.title: Fort Moultrie
fields.description: The first fort on Sullivan's Island was still incomplete when Commodore Sir Peter Parker and nine warships attacked it on June 28, 1776. After a nine-hour battle, the ships were forced to retire. Charleston was saved from British occupation, and the fort was named in honor of its commander, Colonel. William Moultrie. In 1780 the British finally captured Charleston, abandoning it only on the advent of peace.

fields.title: Fort Sumter
fields.description: Where the American Civil War Gegan. fields.title: Gray Mule
fields.description: A spotted gray and white mule is facing away from the viewer in a grassy field behind a whitwashed farm fence. The fence frames the mule, who is just to the right of center. The mule's tail is brushed slightly to the left and the mule has its head placed down near the ground, turned slightly to the left so that you can see its ele and ears. It appears to be eating grass but noticing the viewer. In the distance to the left of the gray mule in the foreground a large brown mule is munching grass. To the left of the brown mule is a small tree with three trunk segments. To the right of the gray mule is a larger tree (live oak?) in the distance. In the far distance the flat green field appears to meet with some low dark green hills. The shadows are short indicating that the image is near noon time. The sky is blue with strands of white puffy clouds.
fields.notes:
copyright_x0020_submitted: 2004
last: Leftwich
first: Willie and Curtis
date_x0020_purchased: 8/23/04

fields.title: Green Weed Grotto
fields.description: A landscape painting of a stone waterfall with three streams of flow emerging from a thick tropical forest to feed small rivulets that from into a stream and a small pond. Round stones form a path for the water down from the waterfall and into the foreground. Left of the waterfall, in the flat foreground, six small palms and four palmettos in two rows grow. Tiny red flowers punctuate the green carpet to the right of the waterfall while delicate purple water hyacynths bloom in the pond below. Distant trees on the left emerge from the fog.

fields.title: Gullah Mask
fields.description: An esoteric mask with the top of the skull on the mask painted reflecting two white sheets flowing in the wind that are separated in the middle with a blue sky with white clouds.  The face of the mask is painted to look like green grass.  The lips and bottom of the nose near the nostrils and are dark green along with the shadows under the flowing sheets.  There is a yellow butterfly painted on each cheek of the mask. This is a mask of the Gullah lowcountry of South Carolina

fields.title: Heliconias I
fields.signature: Lower right hand side of Heliconia
fields.description: A still life of the flowers of a heliconia plant with a teal-blue background. The Heliconia inflorescences are made of bracts that start at their base in a pale orange color and end with a bright red-orange lip. The stems are brilliant green highlighted with yellow. The pallete knife technique is very clear in these paintings. This painting shows three inflorescences with three stems. On the left, behind the central inflorescence, there is an inflorescence with four alternate bracts. In the center of the painting a series of three stems make a V-shape. There are two stems on the left of the central inflorescence and one large stem on the right. One of the two stems on the left continues out of the image and the other appears to be broken off.  The central inflorescence is made of four alternate bracts. Behind the large stem on the right is a smaller inflorescence made up of two alternate bracts. The shadow behind the flowers is harsh and suggests a light sources from the immediate right of the painting and a background near the flowers. There is a deep shadow surrounding the leftmost inflorescence.

fields.title: Heliconias III

The Heliconia inflorescences are made of bracts that start at their base in a pale orange color and end with a bright red-orange lip. The stems are brilliant green highlighted with yellow. The pallete knife technique is very clear in these paintings. This painting shows two inflorescences with three stems. This painting shows two inflorescences in close paralel, with the right inflorescence overlapping the left. There is a substantial shadow in the center of this painting between the two inflorescences.

There is a white ribbon tied around the brim of her hat with two tales of the ribbon flowing upard from the hat.  There is a blue sky above and below the sheets.  The foreground is a light green yellow grass, floowed by a darker green, a lighter green and a horizon that may contain dark green trees.  There are no clouds in the sky.

fields.title: Mule Lane
fields.description: A view of a dirt or gravel road as it curves from the right top to the left bottom of the painting from tree-level above the road. The road is dotted in brownish specks and is deeply rutted down the center. The sky at the top of the painting is dark blue and a white full moon is rising in a partly cloudy sky in the far distance. A bright red fence lines the road on both sides, following its curve. Behind the fence on the left side there are four (apple?) trees with delicate green leaves and purple trunks. A mass of the same kind of trees are also located behind the red fence on the left side of the road. In the distance, beneath the rising moon, a pale white/bluish truck (Jeep?) is making its way down the road. The truck's bed is obscured by trees and a reflection on the window renders the driver invisible. The landscape in the distance is flat and grassy, dotted with shadows from the brilliant moonlight.
fields.notes:

fields.title: Night
fields.description: A black mule with purple spots looks at the viewer from over a white farm fence with two fenceposts in the image. The fence is covered in shadows like dappled light through the trees and it reflects the red-pink of the sky. A red bucket hangs on the left fencepost leaning with its top opening towards the right. The mule is wearing a yellow blinder. The field in which the mule stands is full of tall swirling grass and has three (live oak?) trees -- one near, one farther away to the left and one farthest away to the left. The shadows are directly under the trees. The sky is brilliant red and tinged with blue. In the field to the left of the mule a red rooster struts with two chickens in attendance -- one blue and one yellow.
fields.notes:
copyright_x0020_submitted: 2004
last: Leftwich
first: Willie and Curtis

fields.title: Nude in Olive
fields.style: Abstract/modern. Recalls Brancuzi and Henry Moore's figures.
fields.description: Pastel on paper. Abstract drawing of a large, nude woman. She is defined by geometric shapes - ovals, footballs, circles and other curved shapes. Different colors of green and black define her ample figure. Gray background and lime green floor.
fields.notes: comments: Pastel is unstable and rubbs off on other surfaces.

fields.title: Nude In Two Parts
fields.description: Pastel figure of a nude woman. Outlined in heavy black line. The body is gray with contours and shapes defined by light blue and blue colors. Fuschia is at the eye lids. Wide white area around head - maybe hair.
fields.notes:
note: Two parts
shape: 25 by 19
comments: Work on two separate pieces of paper to create one image.

fields.title: Old Thoughts
fields.description: A painting of a woman standing in the finger marshes of the Lowcountry of South Carolina.  The woman is viewed from the back and is looking out over the marshes and out to the sea.  She is wearing a white dress with a blue horizontal trim near the hem of the dress, and she is holding in her left arm a large sweetgrass basket.  She is also wearing a sweetgrass hat with a white trim near the brim of the hat.  There are floating young white thunderclouds developing in the sky.  The thunderclouds are reflected in the marsh waters.  The painting has an outstanding balance and the atmosphere is one of silence and space.
fields.notes:

fields.title: Oscar at Work
fields.description: A view from behind and above a dark black man in a blue and white striped (vertical stripes) collared longsleeve shirt and a blue striped hat as he (apparently) ploughs a cornfield with a mule. Both the man and the mule are facing away from the viewer. They are situated just to the right of the center of the painting. The mule is dark black with blueish and some yellowish spots. The corn rows are (like the shirt stripes) vertical and have small corn plants growing in them. They lead to a body of blue and yellow dappled water in the distance. Past the blue water are some rolling hills. The sky is full of white fluffy clouds and has a yellow tinge.

fields.title: Paradise Series III
fields.description: This is the 3rd painting in a series of 4 surrealistic paintings created to reflect an abstract esoteric spirit of a head floating over the marshland waters.  The cool atmosphere of the painting is enhanced by the blue water with the blue head of a man whose bottom portion of the face is over the blue water and the upper head of the face is in front of green marshland grasses.  There are two colorful blue and red birds of paradise with yellow heads flying towards the floating head.  One bird appears to be approaching the nostril of the floating head.  The result evokes an eerie mood of a quiet ever present mysterious spirit rising from the marshlands.

fields.title: Passage
fields.description: A dramatic painting created for the image to used for the promotion of the Cincinnati Opera around the life of Margaret Garner a slave in 1850 that escaped with her husband and children from slave owners in Kentucky and fled to Ohio.  The painting features a Black Slave viewed from the back.  She appears to be walking in a field of grass surrounded by large oak trees.  She is looking toward the horizon that is beyond a small river.  The horizon has red clouds and there are three large black eagle that appear to be flying into the red horizon.  The Woman is wearing a dark purple blue full skirt with a white lining around the hem of the skirt.  She has a red apron that is flowing outwards from the skirt.  She blouse is a lightly lighter purple than the dress.  She has a white head scarf with the ribbons of the scarf flowing into the breeze.   4949 SW Meadows Rd, Sluite 475 - Lake Oswego, OR 97035 (503) 697-1040 Ext 14

fields.title: Patterned Sheets
fields.description: A woman seen from the upper two thirds of her body from the back.  She is stadning tetween two rows of sheets on a closeline.  Both of her arms are somewhat outstretched as if with a movement of excitement.  Thjere are six buttons on the back of her dress.  The sheets in the foreground are flying in the breeze which afford the viewer to see the figure between the rows of seets.  The foreground sheets appear to have ovual off blue rings in the sheets.  There is one lone closepin on the second line of sheets on the left hand side.

fields.title: Radiance
fields.description: A young woman in a brilliant almost velvet red dress with a white bow around her wait and white trim on the bottom of the dress.  She appears almost horizontal spinning in a rope swing with her brown hair flowing in the wind.  She is an olive skinned African-American woman.  The rope swing hangs under a tree, but you cannot see the white tree only a part of the limb.  She is winging over the water and there are white clouds throughout the horizon.  Her face is toward the viewer.
fields.notes:
last: Lutgert
first: Scott
salutation: Mr.
address: 1395 Great Egret Trail
city: Naples
state: FL
zip: 34105
telephone: 239 273-7600 - Cell
notes: "Radiance" captures Green's love for the simple pleaures of life as well as his deep respect for nature and one's environment.  Green is noted for his use of clouds and unique renditions of water typlical of the skies over the South Carolina marshlands.
Purchased by Scott Lutgert on 3/12/2005 when he and hiw wife Simone visited the studio.  He understand that it is to be at the Harmon Meek Gallery on April 11 - 22nd for an exhibition 2005 - painting then to be delivered to Scott Lutgert.
date_x0020_purchased: 3/12/2005

fields.title: Red Wagon
fields.description: Beneath a purple sky filled with puffy white clouds on a flat plain of grasses runs a rutted, straight dirt road. On this road a red wagon with white wagon wheels moves away from th eground-level viewer. A small redish hound-type dog walks away from the viewer alongside the wagon. Two ladies in antique-style white dresses and straw hats are driving the wagon, which is led by a black mule (barely visible over the left shoulder of the left side passenger). The passenger on the left is slightly larger than the one on the right. The flat fields of grasses on either side of the wagon and the road are peppered with purple and green. On the left side of the painting is a white house with a front porchnestled among three trees. To the right and slightly closer is a large oak tree with the roots and the bottom portion of the tree painted white. A line of grasses runs directly down the middle of the road.
fields.notes:
copyright_x0020_submitted: 2004
last: Leftwich
first: Willie and Curtis

fields.title: Robert Smalls
fields.signature: Upper Left Corner of the Painting
fields.description: Robert Smalls (April 5, 1839 – February 23, 1915) was an enslaved African American who, during and after the American Civil War, became a ship's pilot, sea captain, and politician. He freed himself, his crew and their families from slavery on May 13, 1862, by commandeering a Confederate transport ship, the CSS Planter, in Charleston harbor, and sailing it to freedom beyond the Federal blockade. His example and persuasion helped convince President Lincoln to accept African-American soldiers into the Union Army. Smalls was born in Beaufort, South Carolina. After the American Civil War, he became a politician, winning election to the South Carolina State legislature and the United States House of Representatives. As a politician, Smalls authored state legislation providing for South Carolina to have the first free and compulsory public school system in the United States, and founded the Republican Party of South Carolina. He was the lastRepublican to represent South Carolina's 5th congressional district until 2010.

fields.title: Selene
fields.description: Commissioned by Andrew Epting on 12-13-2012 and it was completed in April 2013. An image of a standing nude woman wading in the water up to her ankles looking out over the sea.  The painting was drawn using Higgins Calligraphy Waterproof Black Ink on Arches 300 lb cold press watercolor paper. The painting is of the Greek Goddess Selene.  Selene is mainly known for being the goddess of the moon, though she is also known as a deity presiding over the night, ocean tides, magic, childbirth, dew, nursing, and the months.  So by extension, her domain encompasses everything the moon can be connected to.

fields.title: Southern Shade
fields.description: An impressionistic representational painting of a beautiful Lowcountry woman viewed from a left profile view from the waist up as she is standing in front of white flowing sheets.  She, as well is dressed in white and is wearing a magnificent straw colored large sweetgrass hat with a white ribbon flowing from the rim of the hat simulating a slight breeze.  She is almost blue black and her brilliant dark skin is highlighted by a string of white pearls around her neck.  She is wearing a gold circle earring.  There is a small yellow butterfly resting on her left shoulder.  There is a field of green grass seen between the sheets that serve as a background to highlight her dress.  There is a hint of a blue sky with scattered white clouds in the upper right edge of the painting creating a sense of depth and space.  Just below the skyline there is one lone wooden clothes pin holding one of the sheets on the line.  The painting is signed in the lower right corner of the painting.
fields.notes:

The two men are driving a mule cart through the woods with twobrown spotted mules, yoked and blindered. A taller white man wears a red shirt and has a straw hat on the left of a smaller dark black man who wears a blue shirt and has a straw hat as well. The white man's hat is ruffled at the edges. The black man's hat is turned down with a smooth brim and a green hatband.

fields.title: Tabernacle Baptist Church
fields.description:
Built in: 1840 Remodeled in: 1893
The Tabernacle, a meeting house and lecture room, was built by Beaufort Baptist Church in 1840s, perhaps on site of a praise house built before 1832. On 1 September 1863, Tabernacle Baptist Church was organized by the Rev. Soloman Peck of Boston, Massachusetts, with much of its 500 member African-American congregation coming from the Beaufort Baptist Church. The new congregation acquired this building and continues to use it for worship. Damaged in the hurricane of 1893, it was rebuilt and rededicated. The cemetery contains graves of Bythewood family (the earliest dating to 1817) suggesting an early-19th century burial ground occupies site. A memorial to Robert Smalls is also located in the cemetery where Smalls and his first wife Hannah are buried. Robert Smalls (1839-1915), was born into slavery. In 1862, while working as part of the slave crew of the Confederate steamer “The Planter,” Smalls managed to capture the ship and turn it over to Union forces. After the war, his distinguished career of public service included election to the South Carolina House of Representatives (1868-1870) and Senate (1870-1875), as well as four terms in the U. S. House of Representatives (1875-1879, 1882-1887). Smalls also served as a major general in the state militia and later served as Port Collector for Beaufort.

fields.title: The Bottle Tree
fields.description: A small painting of a Bottle Tree that appears to be made from an old cypress.  There are white rocks surrounding the base of the tree.  The tree is covered with red yellow and green bottles.  The bottle tree was often seen in rural Southern communities in South Carolina.  It was used by some of the elders as an old custom to protect a home from eveil spirits.  The origin of the tradition stems from the 9th century Conga where hand-blown glass was hung on trees as a tailsman against eveil.

fields.title: The Proposal
fields.description: Acrylic on Paper. A woman seen sitting on a swing from a left profile position.  She is wearing a yellow polka dot dress. there is a blue and orange flower ribbon on the lower end of the rope of the swing under her left hand.  She is wearing white socks with orange trim.  She has a yellow hat with a blue and white scarf around the brim.  She is looking toward a man satdning who is wearing puble pants, and orange belt, a back and white verticale striped shirt with a red vest.  He has a straw hat with a band on the brim the same color as the lday'ds dress.  There is a tree in the right background.  Branches of a tree highlight the foreground . There is a sea in the background. and white\nclouds in the sky.
fields.notes: last: Weedman/Green

fields.title: Torch Song 1/75
fields.description: A yellow-haired, chocolate-skinned woman in a purple strapless evening gown and matching purple gloves faces the viewer and sings into a teal microphone, which she holds in her right hand. Her left hand is on her left hip and her left arm is somewhat obscured to the forearm by her round hip. The cord from the microphone seems to go to the unseen left hand as it makes a loop from her left hip straight up the middle of the front of her body to the microphone. The woman's eyes are closed. She is wearing large yellow hoop earrings grey eyeshadow and red lipstick. Her mouth is open and her eyes are closed. Approximately one-third of her 60s style hairdo is cut off at the top of the painting. The woman's ample hips continue to the bottom of the painting, which stops just above where her knees might be. In the lower background, a dark round shadow looms. In the upper background a pattern (wallpaper? Stage design?) of bright red paisley-shapes are on a field of bright blue. The stage lighting is harsh and from the front.
fields.notes: notes: This original silk screen print was produced at the Department of Art at the University of South Carolina in Columbia, SC The artist, Jonathan Green worked in collaboration with Gene Speer, Master Printer, for the printing and trial proofing and with Mary Robinson, Professor of Printmaking, for quality observation, assistance in printing and consultation with the artists. Assistant printers included Micah Cash, Jonathan Goley, Sara Kennedy and Denton Smith. Jonathan Green painted an initial study of Dance Hall Romance in gouache on paper, which guided th emaking of hand cut and painted stencils used in the printing. Eighteen layers of silkscreen inks were used in the printing of this silkscreen. The preliminary study for this print was returned to Jonathan Green Studios, Inc. for its archival files. There are no prior or  ater editions in this series of original prints. Printed on Stonehenge Wrm White 250g, 9o Weight. Paper size 37" x 30"

Approximately one-third of her 60s style hairdo is cut off at the top of the painting. The woman's ample hips continue to the bottom of the painting, which stops just above where her knees might be. In the lower background, a dark round shadow looms. In the upper background a pattern (wallpaper? Stage design?) of bright red paisley-shapes are on a field of bright blue. The stage lighting is harsh and from the front.
fields.notes: notes: This original silk screen print was produced at the Department of Art at the University of South Carolina in Columbia, SC The artist, Jonathan Green worked in collaboration with Gene Speer, Master Printer, for the printing and trial proofing and with Mary Robinson, Professor of Printmaking, for quality observation, assistance in printing and consultation with the artists. Assistant printers included Micah Cash, Jonathan Goley, Sara Kennedy and Denton Smith. Jonathan Green painted an initial study of Dance Hall Romance in gouache on paper, which guided th emaking of hand cut and painted stencils used in the printing. fields.title: Totems #1
fields.description: Ink wash on paper with pastel. Subject: African totems or fertility gods - in a triangular shape. Green background and with a band of orange, yellow and red at the top. Totems are highlighted with pastel - in green, violet, and blue. Copper and silver colored ink are also used on the totems.
fields.condition: Good. Water damage at upper right.
fields.notes: shape: 30 by 22.5

fields.title: Totems #2
fields.description: Ink wash on paper. Subject: African totems or fertility gods  in a up and down repeated pattern which would allow the work to be oriented both ways. Brown totems with gold, copper and silver. Four full totems and a partial totem. They are placed in a rectangular area with a red and gold plaid pattern in the background. This is floating on the final background which is red with dark red/maroon splashes and big areas of color.
fields.notes: shape: 30 by 22.5

fields.title: Washing Line Walk
fields.description: A dark black woman in a broad-brimmed, brown straw(?) hat and a white dress blown up slightly from a wind (blowing from the background/right to the forefront/left) walks away from the viewer towards a laundry line with two windblown sheets (being blown towards the viewer). She is wearing little brown shoes. The sky above is cloudless and blue above the sheets while the ground beneath her feet is grassy green. The nearly perpendicular nature of the shadows indicate that it is near noontime. It appears that the woman is turning her head slightly left.

fields.title: White Waves
fields.signature: Upper right corner of the painting
fields.description: An almost magic realism detail of a magnificent hand braided sweetgrass hat being worn by a woman in an off blue blouse shirt with a v-neck.  There is a white scarf band around the brim of the hat with two flowing white ribbons behind the hat that creates an impression of rolling white waves that are enhanced against the impressionistic painted white linen sheets flowing from the an imaginary closeline in the background.  The woman appears to be looking down as the brim of the hat totally covers her face and all the viewer sees is the dark skin of the woman seen in v-neck blouse.  There is a hint of rich green grass in the foreground and a slight vertical slip of the sky in the upper background seen through a break in the hanging sheets. There is an atmosphere of elegance and silence conveyed in the painting that creates a mood of incredible dignity and respect.

fields.title: Willow Root Pole

A blue black African American woman in a white dress is facing the viewer in the foreground. She has a pearl necklace and pear bracelents on each wrist.  She is wearing a red hat with white ribbons flowing upard from the hat. She is hold in her hands a horizontal willow root red and white walking pole. fields.title: Willow Wash
fields.description: A dark-skinned woman stands in the right foreground and faces the viewer in a flat, green field. She is wearing a light blue dress with white buttons and trim. She also wears a brown hat, which is lined in light blue. A white ribbon hatband is around the hat and appears to be tied in a bow around her chin. The woman appears to be holding her dress against the tug of the wind. She also holds two balloons -- a yellow one on the left and a red one on the right. Behind her two sheets hang to dry. Both sheets are being blown by the wind. A (?willow) branch helps bolster the laundry line. The sheet on the left is trimmed in yellow while the sheet on the right is trimmed in teal ribbon. Both sheets are waving very high in the wind.  Dark green topography is in the far distance. Highly defined shadows beneath the sheets and the woman's dress indicate that it is near noontime.

fields.title: Young Maude
fields.description: A young dark black farmhand feeds a young brown mule a carrot in a white fenced corral.The young farmhand is wearing a brown, broad-brimed cowboy-type hat with a white ribbon on it. In they hat is a small red, black and white feather. The boy is wearing a white longsleeve shirt with the sleeves rolled up, (bluejeans?) dungarees and black boots. He has a taupe colored vest that matches his hat. There is a small hill of dirt in the corral behind them. Beyond the corral, in a grassy field, three (horses? cows? mules?) farm animals graze. Two of the animals are black (left side) and one is brownish (on the right side). The viewer looks from the other side of a close white fence of the corral, which is dappled with shadows from nearby trees.
fields.notes:
copyright_x0020_submitted: 2004
last: Leftwich
first: Willie and Curtis
date_x0020_purchased: 8/23/04
